title: cca 1850-1900 condensed serif
content:
A long shot but does anyone has an idea what could get close to this?  
Unfortunately this is the only image I have....

tnx

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [rudolfinum.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018223314/http:/typophile.com/files/rudolfinum.jpg) | 20.77 KB |
author: cicifoo

comments.content:
Not quite, but let's say a bold condensed version of Hermann Zapf's Melior?

Or what about this one?  
 [http://www.sinnebild.se/font/large/havel.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018223314/http:/www.sinnebild.se/font/large/havel.html "http://www.sinnebild.se/font/large/havel.html")

This seems like a perfect time to bring up Miles Newlyn's [Verona](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018223314/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/SerifGuide/serifsamples/serif_uz/verona_x&y_full.gif) again, which he told us was based on Melior.

- Mike Yanega

Verona seems close yeah... this is going to be harder than I thought...  
tnx...

Mike Cina's [Cam](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018223314/http:/www.identifont.com/show?93B) is an all-caps font that could use the W upside-down to make this M. Vertically stretching a bit would enhance the resemblance to your stone letters that have probably little connection to fonts as we know them.

- Mike Yanega

Thank you... Yes, it turned into a custom job... I found this one the most usefull as a starting point though [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/itc-clearface/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018223314/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/itc-clearface/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/itc-clearface/")
